This process describes Group II intron splicing, where the intron forms a lariat structure by the 2' OH of a specific adenine attacking the 5' splice site. The 3' OH of the 5' exon then attacks the 3' splice site, resulting in the ligation of the exons. This mechanism is distinct from Group I intron splicing, which involves a different pathway involving a guanine residue cofactor's 3' OH attacking the 5' phosphate of the intron.
